DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Breast Carcinoma Focus Assessment Count
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The quantity related to the assessment of the number of foci in breast carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Breast Carcinoma Focus Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the assessment of foci in breast carcinoma.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.:Area of greatest concentration, attention, or activity; a central point or locus, especially of an infection.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
Area of greatest concentration, attention, or activity; a central point or locus, especially of an infection.

ReferenceDocuments.name: How many foci of biopsy-prove
ReferenceDocuments.description: How many foci of biopsy-proven breast cancer separated by >=2cm of normal breast tissue are seen by mammogram?
